trigger: <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in rheumatoid arthritis : correlation with inflammation , not disease specificity .

Rheumatoid arthritis synovial tissue was examined and compared with osteoarthritis tissue for the presence of the nuclear transcription factor <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> NF-IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
The region ( lining or sublining ) , cell type , and subcellular distribution ( cytoplasmic or nuclear ) of the expression of C / EBP beta was characterized .
Rheumatoid arthritis synovial fluid and blood and normal peripheral blood were also examined .
<extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was detected in the synovial lining and in sublining cells of synovial tissue from patients with both rheumatoid and osteoarthritis .

A significant ( P < 0.001 and < 0.05 , respectively ) increase in the percentage of cells with nuclear staining was seen in the lining layer , compared to cells in the sublining region , in rheumatoid and osteoarthritis .

In both diseases a strong correlation ( r = 0.79 , P < 0.001 ) was observed between the percentage of cells in the synovial lining that were positive for nuclear <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and lining cell depth .
Two-color immunohistochemistry demonstrated that both macrophages and fibroblast-like synoviocytes were positive for nuclear <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
The presence of <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was confirmed by immunohistochemistry and Western blot analysis with isolated synovial fibroblasts .
Nuclear <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was also detected in rheumatoid synovial fluid monocytes / macrophages , but not in lymphocytes or neutrophils .
Western blot analysis confirmed the presence of <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in these cells .
The intensity of <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> staining was greater ( P < 0.001 ) in synovial fluid monocytes than in those from normal or rheumatoid peripheral blood .

In conclusion , the enhanced nuclear staining for <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the synovial lining , compared to the sublining , suggesting activation in the lining , and the positive correlation of lining layer depth with the percentage of cells in the lining positive for nuclear <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , suggest a potential role for <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in chronic inflammation .

The regulation of the production or activity of <extra_id_0> C/EBP beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , to inhibit inflammatory mediator expression by synovial macrophages and fibroblasts , offers a novel approach to therapeutic intervention .
